dt.t: His car was {wi}demolished{/wi} in the accident.
a filibuster which would effectively {wi}demolish{/wi} the issue
… a performance so awkward and apathetic it instantly appeared to {wi}demolish{/wi} any chance of restoring her declining career …

dt: {bc}to strip of any pretense of {d_link|merit|merit:1} or {d_link|credence|credence}

et: borrowed from Middle French {it}demolir,{/it} extended stem {it}demoliss-{/it} (with final conformed to earlier English verbs with the same ending, as {et_link|nourish|nourish}, {et_link|perish|perish}), borrowed from Latin {it}dēmōlīrī, dēmōlīre{/it} "to throw off, pull down, raze," from {it}dē-{/it} {et_link|de-|de-} + {it}mōlīrī{/it} "to labor to bring about, strive, build, construct." probably derivative of {it}mōlēs{/it} "large mass, massive structure, effort, exertion" {ma}{mat|mole:4|}{/ma}
